subject: Re: [junit] Dependency Testing
msgSnippet: ... When doing tests with parts of my software that need an underlying database, I m always using HSQLDB that gets connected instead of the real database being
messageBody:
Trenton D. Adams schrieb:

> In other words, take some
> data that I'm expecting, and put it in the DB, rather than actually
> "generate" the data. That way, I don't need the nightly job to be part
> of the testing cycle.

When doing tests with parts of my software that need an underlying
database, I'm always using HSQLDB that gets connected instead of
the real database being in use. That way you can fill in exactly
what you want without the problem that e.g. a parallel running test
is interfering.

> Then, all the tests could run independently, and not rely on each other,
> but I could also run them in order manually, to verify that the system
> actually works as a whole.

These are different types of tests and should exist in parallel.
The first gives you immediate feedback if you change something at
one specific part. The latter gives you feedback if the current
change has broken something somewhere else. Both are necessray.
The difference is that the single test should run very fast, allowing
you the check your changes over and over again to realize as soon
as possible in the process that you broke something. The whole
test run can take longer.

My single tests always take only up to a couple of seconds (with
few exceptions) while the complete test including coverage-calculation
takes about one hour (without coverage 20 minutes).

> Then, I could actually have an "OrderedTest"
> that instantiates all my TestCase classes, and calls them in order. That
> in itself would then be it's own separate test.

Personally I don't like these kind of test-classes because I always
forget to add a newly created one (but that be different from you,
so this might be a practicable way).

> Does that sound like a good idea?

It's nothing I'd do, but I don't have a system that is that much
"integrated" that I need to do these kind of tests. So don't ask
me about that. If it works for you, it's fine.

>> If you abstracted the layer between your applicaiton and the messaging
>> system you can simply define a mock that answers the requests for you.
>> That way you don't need to setup anything in advance. I'm doing this
>> here e.g. for testing the parts of our software doing OFTP by ISDN.
>
> Yes, that would be possible, but also a whole heck of a lot of extra
> work. It would probably double the code, perhaps even more. I was trying
> to keep my part of the application simple. :D

Doesn't sound good, maybe you overestimate things a bit. I can
recommend reading the book "Working effectively with legacy code"
by Michael C. Feathers. There are a couple of hints how to get
that kind of code you're talking about under test.

> Also, by doing this, I am still circumventing the testing that actually
> tests to see if the system actually works. And, I don't want to do that,
> as I want to be sure the system actually works, and not just my code.

If you make sure that your code works (and keeps working after
doing changes) you can track down problems occuring in the whole
system much easier than without.

> I
> could do these little abstractions (with a factory, that has test and
> production configurations), and that would test my code, but it would
> not test that my code works with the other system, as I would end up
> having a "fake" layer, pretending to be their system, but never actually
> verifying.

I had good results by using anonymous inner classes:

public void testSomething(){
final int[] channels = new int[]{2};
MyISDNHardware driver = new MyISDNHardware(){
public int getNumberOfBChannels(){
return channels[0];
}
}
// perform the tests that check if the behavior in dependence
// of the number of B-channels is correct
}

That's one of the reasons I don't like singletons. It effectively
prevents you from doing things like these.

>> For this I see Ant or Maven a better fitting tool than JUnit. There
>> you have dependencies and all the things you need for data-transfer,
>> emailing, etc.
>
> I am using Maven, but maven isn't a testing tool. However, it does
> support JUnit.

Of course it's not but you can use it to set up things and call
the Junit-tests in dependence of that.


Regards, Lothar
